summary: This is a letter from defense attorneys Martin G. Weinberg, Reid Weingarten, and Michael Miller to Assistant United States Attorneys, supplementing a discovery request in the case United States v. Jeffrey Epstein. The letter requests preservation and production of documents related to the 2006-2008 investigation, specifically communications and materials from the lead prosecutor (AUSA) in the Southern District of Florida and the FBI, including details about a March 2008 trip to New York and interactions with victims and the Southern District of New York USAO.

events.title: Initial Epstein Investigation
events.description: The period when the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida and the FBI were investigating Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: AUSA Trip to New York
events.description: The lead prosecutor from the Southern District of Florida traveled to New York City, likely to conduct interviews or coordinate with the Southern District of New York USAO.

events.title: Initial Discovery Request
events.description: The defense's first request for discovery was electronically mailed to the prosecution, seeking documents related to the Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA).

events.title: Supplemental Discovery Request
events.description: Defense attorneys sent this letter to supplement their first discovery request, particularizing requests for documents from the 2006-2008 investigation.

keyFacts: The defense is seeking discovery related to the 2006-2008 investigation of Jeffrey Epstein conducted by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida and the FBI.
The request specifically targets documents and communications from the lead prosecutor (AUSA) in that case, including details about a March 2008 trip to New York.
The letter references communications between the Florida USAO and victim witnesses regarding their right to confer with a different U.S. Attorney's Office (Southern District of New York).
The defense seeks information about the sharing of investigatory information between the Southern District of Florida and the Southern District of New York USAO from 2007-2019.
The document indicates the defense is investigating potential issues arising from the prior Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA).
